Unlocking the Potential of Model Calibration in
Federated Learning

Yun-Wei Chu chu198@purdue.edu

Abstract

Over the past several years, various federated learning (FL) methodologies have been developed to improve model accuracy, a primary performance metric in machine learning. However, to utilize FL in practical decision-making scenarios, beyond considering accuracy, the trained model must also have a reliable confidence in each of its predictions, an aspect that has been largely overlooked in existing FL research. Motivated by this gap, we propose Non-Uniform Calibration for Federated Learning (NUCFL), a generic framework that integrates FL with the concept of model calibration. The inherent data heterogeneity in FL environments makes model calibration particularly difficult, as it must ensure reliability across diverse data distributions and client conditions. Our NUCFL addresses this challenge by dynamically adjusting the model calibration objectives based on statistical relationships between each clientâ€™s local model and the global model in FL. In particular, NUCFL assesses the similarity between local and global model relationships, and controls the penalty term for the calibration loss during client-side local training. By doing so, NUCFL effectively aligns calibration needs for the global model in heterogeneous FL settings while not sacrificing accuracy. Extensive experiments show that NUCFL offers flexibility and effectiveness across various FL algorithms, enhancing accuracy as well as model calibration.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has rapidly gained traction as a prominent distributed machine learning approach, enabling collaborative model training across a network of clients by periodically aggregating their local models at a central serverÂ [KonecnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016; McMahan etÂ al., 2017]. Its significance extends to various critical applications, including medical diagnostics, self-driving cars, and multilingual systems, where data privacy and decentralized training are paramount. FL has been widely studied with a focus on improving local model updatesÂ Reddi etÂ al. [2021]; Sahu etÂ al. [2018], refining global aggregation methodsÂ Ji etÂ al. [2019]; Wang etÂ al. [2020a], and enhancing communication efficiencyÂ Sattler etÂ al. [2019]; Diao etÂ al. [2020]. Most of these works in FL consider accuracy as the main performance metric.

Motivation. However, beyond accuracy, in various decision-making scenarios where an incorrect prediction may result in high risk (e.g., medical applications or autonomous driving), it is also crucial for the users to determine whether to rely on the FL modelâ€™s prediction or not for each decision. In particular, users should rely on the neural networkâ€™s decision only when the prediction is likely to be correct. Otherwise, they may need to consider alternatives such as human decision. To achieve this, the trained FL model should have a reliable confidence in each of its predictions, meaning that the confidence of the neural network matches well with its actual accuracy. In centralized settings, recent studies includingÂ Guo etÂ al. [2017] have uncovered that neural networks are often miscalibrated, indicating that the prediction confidence of the model does not accurately reflect the probability of correctness. Handling this miscalibration issue is even more important in many FL use-cases, where an overconfident global model could lead to misinformed decisions with potentially severe consequences for each client.

In centralized training settings, research generally follows two paths to address this miscalibration issue. First, train-time calibration methodsÂ Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b]; Liang etÂ al. [2020]; Liu etÂ al. [2021]; Mukhoti etÂ al. [2020]; Kumar etÂ al. [2018]; MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [2019]; Lin etÂ al. [2017] incorporate explicit regularizers during the training process to adjust neural networks, effectively scaling back over/under-confident predictions. On the other hand, post-hoc calibrationÂ Guo etÂ al. [2017]; Hendrycks & Gimpel [2016]; Hinton etÂ al. [2015]; Kull etÂ al. [2017] transforms the networkâ€™s output vector to align the confidence of the predicted label with the actual likelihood of that label for the sample. Post-hoc calibration methods are applied to the already trained model to improve calibration using an additional holdout dataset. However, an appropriate holdout dataset may not be available in many privacy-sensitive applications, making post-hoc calibration strategies often impractical for FL.

Goals and observations. In this paper, we aim to incorporate model calibration into the FL training process, a problem that has been largely underexplored in existing research. This setting introduces new challenges to improving model calibration, as the heterogeneous data distributions across different clients must be carefully considered. We first observe whether existing train-time calibration methods applied during client-side local training can effectively address calibration needs in FL. To gain insights, in Fig.Â 1, we report accuracy, confidence, and the expected calibration error (ECE) of different methods in different settings. Figs.Â 1(a) to Â 1(b) illustrate the capability of train-time calibration methods to narrow the gap between model confidence and accuracy in centralized learning. A comparison between Figs.Â 1(a) and Â 1(c) reveals that FL experiences more significant model miscalibration than centralized learning. This disparity is likely due to data heterogeneity across distributed FL clients, causing each clientâ€™s local data to have a different impact on calibration performance. When applying auxiliary-based calibration methods, such as DCAÂ Liang etÂ al. [2020] and MDCAÂ Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b] â€“ which add a penalty term to the original classification loss â€“ to FLâ€™s local training (Fig.Â 1(d)), a better ECE is achieved compared to FL without calibration (Fig.Â 1(c)). However, we observe that the model in Fig.Â 1(d) is still not well-calibrated by neglecting global calibration needs in heterogeneous FL settings, resulting in overconfident predictions. We thus pose the following question:

How can we unlock the potential of model calibration in FL while not sacrificing accuracy?

Contributions. In this paper, we propose Non-Uniform Calibration for Federated Learning (NUCFL), a versatile and generic model calibration framework for FL that integrates seamlessly with any existing FL algorithms, such as FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018], ScaffoldÂ Karimireddy etÂ al. [2019], FedDynÂ Acar etÂ al. [2021], and FedNovaÂ Wang etÂ al. [2020b]. Designed to work with any train-time calibration auxiliary loss, NUCFL is a straightforward yet effective solution that dynamically adjusts calibration penalties based on the relationship between global and local distribution. Specifically, our intuition is that if each clientâ€™s local model closely resembles the global model, it is likely that the local model and data represent the global calibration needs well. Therefore, our idea is to choose a large penalty term to improve model calibration for the clients that have a high similarity, while imposing a small penalty for other clients to prioritize accuracy. This non-uniform calibration approach considering data heterogeneity across FL clients significantly minimizes calibration errors without accuracy degradation, as seen in FigureÂ 1(e). Importantly, the flexibility of NUCFL allows for continuous improvement as new FL algorithms or calibration losses are developed. Our key contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    Our work is among the early efforts to conduct a systematic study on model calibration in FL. We study the question: How does model calibration impact the behavior of federated optimization methods?

  • â€¢

    We propose NUCFL, a non-uniform model calibration approach tailored to FL. Our NUCFL dynamically adjusts calibration penalties based on the nuanced relationship between each local model and the global model, effectively capturing data heterogeneity.

  • â€¢

    We conduct extensive experiments demonstrating that NUCFL is highly flexible, seamlessly integrating with 5 different FL algorithms (e.g., FedProx, Scaffold, FedDyn) and various auxiliary-based train-time calibration methods to improve both calibration performance and accuracy.

2 Related Work

Federated learning. FedAvgÂ McMahan etÂ al. [2017] is the pioneering FL algorithm, with numerous adaptations proposed to mitigate the accuracy drop experienced with non-IID data. Much of the research has focused on designing better global aggregation methods to enhance model convergence and performance. Some researchersÂ He etÂ al. [2020]; Lin etÂ al. [2020] replaced weight averaging with model ensemble and distillation, othersÂ Yurochkin etÂ al. [2019]; Wang etÂ al. [2020a] matched local model weights before averaging, and another groupÂ Ji etÂ al. [2019] introduced an attention mechanism to optimize global aggregation. Another significant area has concentrated on optimizing local training protocols to optimize computation and data usage on clientsâ€™ devices. Some researchersÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018]; Acar etÂ al. [2021] employed regularization toward the global model, while [Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019] utilized server statistics to correct local gradients. Additionally, various studies have addressed challenges specific to FL, such as ensuring fairness across all participantsÂ Li etÂ al. [2020], enhancing communication efficiency to minimize bandwidth usageÂ Ko etÂ al. [2023], and addressing privacy concerns inherent in distributed computationsÂ Truong etÂ al. [2020]. However, the main focus of existing FL research is on improving accuracy. The mismatch between confidence and actual accuracy in these works leads to overconfident FL models, making FL inapplicable in high-risk decision-making scenarios. Our work bridges this gap by investigating an overlooked aspect of federated learning: model calibration.

Model calibration. Model calibration techniques can be categorized into post-hoc calibration and train-time calibration methods. Post-hoc methods adjust the model using a hold-out dataset after training. Common examples include Temperature ScalingÂ Guo etÂ al. [2017], which adjusts logits by a scalar learned from a hold-out set before softmax, and Dirichlet CalibrationÂ Kull etÂ al. [2017], which modifies log-transformed class probabilities through an additional network layer. However, in FL applications, an additional validation set is often not available due to privacy issues, making post-hoc calibration methods inapplicable. On the other hand, train-time calibration integrates calibration directly within the training process. Muller et al.Â MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [2019] enhance calibration using label smoothing on soft targets, while Lin et al.Â Lin etÂ al. [2017] use focal loss to minimize the KL divergence between predicted and target distributions. Recently, augmenting standard cross-entropy loss with additional penalty loss terms has become a popular train-time calibration methodÂ Liang etÂ al. [2020]; Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b]; Kumar etÂ al. [2018]. This auxiliary loss penalizes the model when there is a reduction in cross-entropy loss without a corresponding increase in accuracy, often indicative of overfitting. However, as seen in Fig.Â 1, a direct application of these methods still faces limitations, as they are not able to meet the calibration needs considering data heterogeneity across FL clients. Our work fills this gap by taking a non-uniform calibration approach considering the characteristics of FL.

Calibration and Federated Learning

Peng etÂ al. [2024] proposed FedCal, a calibration scaler aggregated solely from local clients, and introduced model calibration for FL. However, FedCal does not consider the interaction between global and local calibration needs, which can lead to a calibration bias towards local heterogeneity. Our model calibration framework addresses this issue by considering the interaction between client and server, thereby better accommodating broader global calibration requirements. Furthermore, while FedCal has shown effectiveness only with FedAvg, our framework aims to provide robust calibration across various FL configurations, enhancing flexibility beyond just FedAvg. It is also worth mentioning that Zhang etÂ al. [2022]; Luo etÂ al. [2021] also use the term â€œcalibrationâ€ in the FL setup. However, we stress that the context of calibration in their work is different from the one in the model calibration literature that considers confidence of the prediction. Zhang etÂ al. [2022]; Luo etÂ al. [2021] focuses on calibrating the classifier to improve the accuracy itself, which can be categorized into conventional FL works that do not consider the error between model confidence and accuracy.

3.2 Model Calibration

In supervised multi-class classification, the input xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X} and label yâˆˆğ’´={1,â€¦,K}ğ‘¦ğ’´1â€¦ğ¾y\in\mathcal{Y}=\{1,...,K\} are random variables following a ground truth joint distribution Ï€â€‹(x,y)=Ï€â€‹(y|x)â€‹Ï€â€‹(x)ğœ‹ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ‹conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘¥\pi(x,y)=\pi(y|x)\pi(x). Let sğ‘ s be the confidence score vector in â„Ksuperscriptâ„ğ¾\mathbb{R}^{K}, with sâ€‹[y]=fâ€‹(x)ğ‘ delimited-[]ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¥s[y]=f(x) representing the confidence that the neural network fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘“â‹…f(\cdot) predicts for a class yğ‘¦y given input xğ‘¥x. The predicted class y^^ğ‘¦\hat{y} is computed as: y^=argâ¡maxyâ¡sâ€‹[y]^ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ delimited-[]ğ‘¦\hat{y}=\arg\max_{y}s[y], with the corresponding confidence s^=maxyâ¡sâ€‹[y]^ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ delimited-[]ğ‘¦\hat{s}=\max_{y}s[y]. A model is considered perfectly calibratedÂ Guo etÂ al. [2017] if:

â„™â€‹(y^=y|s^=p)=p,âˆ€pâˆˆ[0,1].formulae-sequenceâ„™^ğ‘¦conditionalğ‘¦^ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘for-allğ‘01\mathbb{P}(\hat{y}=y|\hat{s}=p)=p,\forall p\in[0,1]. (2)

That is to say, we expect the confidence estimate of the prediction to reflect the true probability of the prediction being accurate. For example, given 100 predictions, each with a confidence of 0.80.80.8, we expect that 80 should be correctly classified. One concept of miscalibration involves the difference between confidence and accuracy, which can be described as:

ğ”¼s^[|(y^=y|s^=p)âˆ’p|].\mathbb{E}_{\hat{s}}[|(\hat{y}=y|\hat{s}=p)-p|]. (3)

The primary goal of model calibration, whether via train-time or post-hoc methods, is to minimize discrepancy (3) to ensure the modelâ€™s confidence accurately reflects its prediction accuracy.

4 Proposed Model Calibration for Federated Learning

4.1 Bridging Federated Learning and Model Calibration

Our approach aims to implement calibration on each FL clientâ€™s local training. Note that in conventional FL algorithms, the loss â„’msubscriptâ„’ğ‘š\mathcal{L}_{m} of client mğ‘šm in (1) can be expressed as follows:

â„’mâ€‹(wm(t,e))=1|ğ’Ÿm|â€‹âˆ‘i=1|ğ’Ÿm|â„“â€‹(wm(t,e);xi,yi),subscriptâ„’ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘’1subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šğ‘–1â„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\mathcal{L}_{m}({w}_{m}^{(t,e)})=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}\sum^{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}_{i=1}\ell({w}_{m}^{(t,e)};x_{i},y_{i}), (4)

where wmsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘šw_{m} is the local model, tğ‘¡t the current global round, eğ‘’e the local iteration index, and â„“â€‹(â‹…)â„“â‹…\ell(\cdot) the loss function (e.g., cross-entropy) applied to a data instance. One can also modify the loss in (4), i.e., by adding a proximal term as in FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018]. Recent studies on calibrationÂ Liang etÂ al. [2020]; Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b] suggest that incorporating an auxiliary loss, which captures the disparity between accuracy and confidence (as in equation (3)), and penalizing the model accordingly, leads to superior performance compared to direct loss type adjustmentsÂ MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [2019]; Brier [1950]; Lin etÂ al. [2017]. These auxiliary loss methods maintain the original classification loss and seamlessly add a penalty, minimizing interference with FL performance, especially since some FL algorithms are specifically designed around their classification loss strategies. This makes the auxiliary loss methods easily applicable and effective across various FL settings.

Proposed framework. Therefore, for client mğ‘šm, we propose to integrate the calibration loss with the FL loss as follows:

In the centralized calibration case, this scalar weight is manually selected to refine the auxiliary calibration loss. However, in our design, we automatically determine Î²msubscriptğ›½ğ‘š\beta_{m} based on the relationship between the server and clients in a FL setup, taking into account the heterogeneity as detailed in SectionÂ 4.2. Advantages and challenges. The differentiability of these auxiliary loss terms ((6) and (7)) facilitates their integration with other application-specific loss functions, allowing them to enhance calibration without significantly impacting the primary classification loss, â„“â„“\ell. This minimizes any adverse effects on performance while correcting calibration errors. For instance, FL algorithms like FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018] and FedNovaÂ Wang etÂ al. [2020b] incorporate custom loss functions within their local modeling function, ClientOPT (outlined in AlgorithmÂ 1), to address deviations from the global model due to non-IID data. Despite these enhancements, it is critical to note that these advanced FL algorithms still fundamentally require a standard classification loss, which they fine-tune for specific objectives. When integrating calibration into the ClientOPT of FL algorithms, we will exclusively calibrate the standard classification loss, maintaining the integrity of other design elements, such as global aggregation, to ensure their original objectives are not compromised. Choosing an appropriate Î²msubscriptğ›½ğ‘š\beta_{m} tailored to each client mğ‘šm is the remaining challenge.

4.2 Non-Uniform Calibration for Federated Learning (NUCFL)

Motivation: Limitation of uniform penalty. In Equation (5), we promote calibration during federated local training by targeting the confidence-accuracy gap in individual local models via auxiliary calibration loss. The main aim of FL is to train a global model capable of effectively handling the global data distribution. Therefore, we aim for calibration to account for the heterogeneity inherent in FL setups, marking a departure from calibration approaches used in centralized learning. Direct application of auxiliary loss calibration methods without adapting to FL characteristics would result in uniform calibration weights, such that Î²1=Î²2=â€¦=Î²msubscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›½2â€¦subscriptğ›½ğ‘š\beta_{1}=\beta_{2}=...=\beta_{m}. This leads to local models being calibrated solely to their respective datasets Dmsubscriptğ·ğ‘šD_{m}, with uniformly small weights biasing calibration toward local heterogeneity, and uniformly large weights potentially neglecting accuracy improvements from classification. Such discrepancies can result in a global model that, while comprising well-calibrated local models, does not achieve optimal performance across the broader distribution. This fixed calibration penalty approach, therefore, risks neglecting the broader global calibration needs necessary for optimal performance across the entire global distribution.

Non-uniform penalty design (NUCFL). Given that each client receives the global model from the previous round as their starting point for each new federated round, this offers an opportunity to indirectly adjust local calibration to mirror global model characteristics. To leverage this, we propose non-uniform calibration for federated learning (NUCFL), which provides a dynamic calibration penalty to local models to better reflect global calibration needs. Drawing inspiration from the concept of similarity characterization in FL techniquesÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018]; Tan etÂ al. [2023], we hypothesize that a local model closely resembling the global model is likely to represent global characteristics well, suggesting that the penalty appropriately reflects the calibration needs of the global model. Conversely, a dissimilar/heterogeneous local model suggests a focus on local objectives (e.g., to improve accuracy) at the expense of global alignment. By adjusting penalties at each local epoch based on the similarity between local and global models, NUCFL ensures that local training enhances both the calibration and accuracy of the global model. As illustrated in Fig.Â 2, we specifically set

Î²m=simâ€‹(Î´(tâˆ’1),Î´m(t,e)),subscriptğ›½ğ‘šsimsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘’\beta_{m}=\texttt{sim}(\delta^{(t-1)},\delta_{m}^{(t,e)}), (8)

where Î´(tâˆ’1)superscriptğ›¿ğ‘¡1\delta^{(t-1)} is the accumulated gradient from the previous round tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1, representing the received global model, while Î´m(t,e)=w(tâˆ’1)âˆ’wm(t,e)superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘š\delta_{m}^{(t,e)}={w}^{(t-1)}-{w}^{(t,e)}_{m} calculates the gradient for client mğ‘šm at local epoch eğ‘’e during round tğ‘¡t. The function sim(â‹…â‹…\cdot) measures similarity between local and global models, generating values between 0 and 1. Specifically, it can use general cosine similarity or more advanced measures like Centered Kernel Alignment (CKA)Â Kornblith etÂ al. [2019].

For instance, if the learned local model is similar to the received global model, indicated by a higher similarity score, it suggests that the local modelâ€™s characteristics align well with those of the global model. In such cases, the calibration penalty applied to the local model is increased to reflect the global calibration needs. Otherwise, i.e., if the similarity score is low, we choose a smaller penalty and instead focus on improving the accuracy. Based on this non-uniform penalty method tailored to FL, our scheme strategically improves model calibration as well as the accuracy.

Remark 1. NUCFL can integrate any auxiliary-based calibration loss and adapt to any FL algorithm regardless of aggregation method or local loss function. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to address model calibration specifically for FL, introducing a tailored calibration method. Similar to most calibration researchÂ Lin etÂ al. [2017]; MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [2019]; Brier [1950]; Kumar etÂ al. [2018]; Mukhoti etÂ al. [2020]; Liu etÂ al. [2021]; Liang etÂ al. [2020]; Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b; a], our work is an empirical study that explores the practical impacts of our methods. This area of research remains challenging, particularly in providing theoretical guarantees for calibration methods, even in centralized settings; we instead substantiate the effectiveness of our method through extensive experiments. We will demonstrate how our strategic approach effectively calibrates FL in SectionÂ 5.2.

Remark 2 (Compatibility with post-hoc calibration). Although our NUCFL is a train-time calibration approach that is applied during FL training, the proposed technique complements post-hoc methods whenever a holdout dataset is available. For example, temperature scaling can be applied to the trained global FL model for further refinement, as empirically demonstrated in SectionÂ 5.2.

5 Experiments

5.1 Experimental Setup

Dataset and model. We conduct experiments using four image classification datasets commonly utilized in FL researchÂ Caldas etÂ al. [2018]; McMahan etÂ al. [2017]; Mohri etÂ al. [2019]: MNISTÂ LeCun etÂ al. [1998], FEMNISTÂ Cohen etÂ al. [2017], CIFAR-10Â Krizhevsky [2009], and CIFAR-100Â Krizhevsky [2009]. For the MNIST and FEMNIST datasets, we use a CNNÂ LeCun & Bengio [1998] with two 5x5 convolution layers, each followed by 2x2 max pooling, and fully connected layers with ReLU activation. We use AlexNetÂ Krizhevsky etÂ al. [2012] with five convolution layers for the CIFAR-10/100 datasets.

FL data distribution. In the IID setup, data samples from each class are distributed equally to M=50ğ‘€50M=50 clients. To simulate non-IID conditions across clients, we follow Hsu etÂ al. [2019]; Nguyen etÂ al. [2023]; Chen etÂ al. [2023] to partition the training set into M=50ğ‘€50M=50 clients using a Dirichlet distribution with Î±âˆˆ[0.5,0.1,0.05]ğ›¼0.50.10.05\alpha\in[0.5,0.1,0.05].

Calibration baselines. We compare our method against models trained using Cross-Entropy (Uncal.), representing training without calibration, and others such as Focal Loss (FL)Â Lin etÂ al. [2017], Label Smoothing (LS)Â MÃ¼ller etÂ al. [2019], Brier Score (BS)Â Brier [1950], MMCEÂ Kumar etÂ al. [2018], FLSDÂ Mukhoti etÂ al. [2020], MbLSÂ Liu etÂ al. [2021], DCAÂ Liang etÂ al. [2020], and MDCAÂ Hebbalaguppe etÂ al. [2022b]. Detailed parameters for each calibration baseline are provided in the AppendixÂ A.1.

FL algorithms and setups. We conduct model calibration on five well-known FL algorithms, including FedAvgÂ McMahan etÂ al. [2017], FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018], ScaffoldÂ Karimireddy etÂ al. [2019], FedDynÂ Acar etÂ al. [2021], and FedNovaÂ Wang etÂ al. [2020b]. We run each FL algorithm for 100 rounds, evaluating the final global model, with 5 epochs for each local training. We use the SGD optimizer with a learning rate of 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}, weight decay of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}, and momentum of 0.90.90.9. For additional details on the training specifics of each algorithm, please see AppendixÂ A.2.

Auxiliary loss and similarity measures for NUCFL. We implement our framework using two auxiliary-based calibration losses, â„“dâ€‹câ€‹asubscriptâ„“ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘\ell_{dca} and â„“mâ€‹dâ€‹câ€‹asubscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘\ell_{mdca}. [2019]â€“which output a similarity score ranging from 0 (not similar at all) to 1 (identical) for evaluating the similarity between the learned local model and the global model. We refer to configurations using our technique as â€œNUCFL(âˆ—âˆ—\ast + âŠšâŠš\circledcirc),â€ where âˆ—âˆ—\ast denotes auxiliary calibration losses â„“dâ€‹câ€‹asubscriptâ„“ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘\ell_{dca}/â„“mâ€‹dâ€‹câ€‹asubscriptâ„“ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘\ell_{mdca} and âŠšâŠš\circledcirc denotes similarity measurements COS/L-CKA/RBF-CKA, resulting in six configurations for our methods.

Evaluation metrics. [2015], a commonly used metric, approximates calibration error (3) by dividing predictions into Iğ¼I bins and calculating a weighted average of the discrepancies between accuracy and confidence across these bins. 5.2 Experimental Results

Can train-time calibration apply to federated learning? We first compare train-time calibration in traditional centralized training versus non-IID federated learning. We train a model on the entire CIFAR-100 training dataset for 100 epochs with various train-time calibration methods, and present the results in TableÂ 6 of AppendixÂ B.1. Results show that most baselines effectively calibrate in centralized settings, maintaining accuracy and exhibiting lower calibration errors. Yet, when these train-time calibration techniques are applied to FL, as depicted in TableÂ 1, these methods often underperform in calibration and accuracy. Notably, methods like DCA and MDCA that includes an auxiliary loss for calibration show robustness in federated settings. They maintain the primary classification objective while penalizing miscalibration, preserving confidence without affecting classification, distinguishing them in FL environments.

The effects of confidence calibration on FL. TablesÂ 1 and 2 show performance and calibration metrics for various calibration applied to FL algorithms under non-IID scenarios using CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST datasets. Among these baselines, auxiliary-based methods like DCA and MDCA consistently show superior performance, with comparable accuracy and lower calibration error. However, our method outperforms them, as evidenced by the superior performance of NUCFL (DCA/MDCA + âŠšâŠš\circledcirc) over DCA/MDCA, highlighting the importance of our non-uniform penalty, which is specifically tailored to address global calibration needs during local training. The superior performance of NUCFL, incorporating different similarity measurements and various types of auxiliary loss punishment, demonstrates its flexibility and effectiveness. Furthermore, the consistent improvement of our framework across various FL algorithms illustrates its adaptability and robustness in diverse settings. See AppendixÂ B.2 for more results including other datasets and data distributions.

Mitigating over/under-confidence. The results in TablesÂ 1 and 2 show that our method improves SCE and ECE over the baselines, but they highlight whether they correct for over-confidence or under-confidence. To clarify this, we present reliability diagramsÂ Degroot & Fienberg [1983]; Niculescu-Mizil & Caruana [2005], which visually compare predicted probabilities to actual outcomes, plotting expected accuracy against confidence. If the model is perfectly calibrated (i.e. if â„™â€‹(y^=yâˆ—|sâ€‹[y^])=sâ€‹[y^]â„™^ğ‘¦conditionalsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ delimited-[]^ğ‘¦ğ‘ delimited-[]^ğ‘¦\mathbb{P}(\hat{y}=y^{*}|s[\hat{y}])=s[\hat{y}]), then the diagram should plot the identity function. Any deviation from a perfect diagonal represents miscalibration. In Fig.Â 3, we present reliability histograms for non-IID FL using various calibration methods, where each FL method yields over-confident predictions. This means that, for example, if a model predicts the probability of a class kğ‘˜k from {1,â€¦,K}1â€¦ğ¾\{1,...,K\} as 0.7, we would expect it to be correct in 70 out of 100 cases. However, if the actual number of correct predictions are less than 70, the model is considered over-confident. Such over-confidence can be problematic, especially in critical applications like medical diagnostics, where it could lead to under-treatment and serious health risks. Our methods show a smaller gap (red region) and lower ECE, effectively mitigating over-confidence. For details on how our method also tackles under-confidence, please refer to AppendixÂ B.3.

Effectiveness of our design. We explore model calibration on various FL settings, analyzing the effects of different non-IID degrees Î±ğ›¼\alpha, numbers of clients Mğ‘€M, and percentages of participating clients per round. Fig. 4 shows the accuracy and calibration results of FedAvg across various configurations on the MNIST dataset, where we adjust one variable at a time from the default setting: M=50ğ‘€50M=50, Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5, 100% participation. Across all settings, our method consistently demonstrates robust calibration. Importantly, our NUCFL maintains effectiveness in more challenging conditions, such as with lower Î±ğ›¼\alpha values indicating higher non-IID disparity or reduced participant numbers per round. This demonstrates the adaptability of our approach in varied and complex FL environments.

Calibration strategy validation. Our calibration strategy applies a higher auxiliary penalty loss to local models that significantly deviate from the received global model, addressing global calibration needs during local training. To validate the soundness of our design, we experiment with an opposite logic, where a higher penalty is applied to local clients more similar to the received global model. We specifically adjust the weight Î²msubscriptğ›½ğ‘š\beta_{m} for each client mğ‘šm to simâ€‹(Î´(tâˆ’1),Î´m(t,e))âˆ’1simsuperscriptsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘’1\texttt{sim}(\delta^{(t-1)},\delta_{m}^{(t,e)})^{-1}. We conducted this destructive experiment to assess whether this approach affects FL and to validate our original calibration logic. In TableÂ 3, we applied a reverse penalty strategy to optimal configurations of our method (i.e., NUCFL (DCA+L-CKA) and (NDCA+L-CKA)) on the CIFAR-100 dataset. The results show that using reversed logic negatively impacts the system, leading to a calibration penalty biased towards local heterogeneity and ignoring global calibration needs, thus degrading the FL systemâ€™s performance. This even resulted in poorer performance compared to uncalibrated FL as shown in TableÂ 1. This experiment confirms the soundness of our design logic, which strategically prioritizes global calibration needs during local training and suggests the benefits of adhering to our approach to avoid disadvantageous effects.

Comparison with the existing model calibration baseline for FL. We now conduct comparisons with the only existing model calibration framework for FL, FedCalÂ Peng etÂ al. [2024]. TableÂ 4 displays the calibration results of our method alongside the baseline using FedAvg under non-IID conditions (Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5) on CIFAR-100 datatset. For the scaler used in their work, we adhered to their design, employing an MLP with layer sizes of 100-64-64-100. We see that our proposed NUCFL has shown superior performance compared to FedCal. While the use of a scaler aggregated solely from local clients can help reduce global ECE, it often overlooks the essential interaction between global and local calibration needs. Our method addresses this by considering these interactions, thus avoiding biases toward local heterogeneity and better accommodating the broader global calibration requirements, a challenge that the aggregation methods might not fully resolve. More comparisons using other datasets are available in AppendixÂ B.4.

Compatibility with post-hoc calibration. Temperature scaling (TS)Â Guo etÂ al. [2017] is one of the most effective post-hoc calibration methods, which adjusts a modelâ€™s logits by a scaling factor to calibrate confidence scores without affecting accuracy. Like all post-hoc methods, TS requires a hold-off dataset to tune the model and learn the calibration parameter (i.e., temperature). However, this need conflicts with the data privacy policies of FL, making TS impractical in such settings. For this analysis, we set aside these privacy concerns to compare with TS, assuming that data from each client is available at the server. Under these assumptions, we conduct non-IID (Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5) FedAvg and sample five images from each client to create a server dataset for post-hoc calibration. TableÂ 5 compares train-time and post-hoc calibration methods using the CIFAR-100 dataset. Results show TS outperforming some train-time methods, like MDCA, while our method still provides superiority in both accuracy and calibration error. Recall from Remark 2 that our NUCFL can also be complemented by post-hoc methods when a holdout dataset is available for refining the global model. We apply post-hoc calibration on the global model using TS after train-time calibration during local training. This combined approach shows improved performance over train-time calibration alone. Notably, integrating TS with NUCFL yields the best results, significantly reducing error.

Further experiments. Additional results on varying degrees of non-IIDness, evaluations across datasets, and discussions on how our method tackles the over/under-confidence problem are available in AppendixÂ B.

6 Conclusion

We conducted one of the earliest systematic study on model calibration for FL and introduced a novel framework, NUCFL, designed to ensure a well-calibrated global model. NUCFL measures the similarity between client and server models and dynamically adjusts calibration penalties for each client, addressing both heterogeneity and global calibration needs effectively. Through extensive experiments, NUCFL demonstrated significant improvements over existing calibration methods, proving its adaptability with various types of auxiliary calibration penalties and compatibility across different FL algorithms. Our research seeks to deepen understanding of the underlying effects of model calibration on FL, enhancing the trustworthiness of FL systems.

A.2 Federated Algorithms

For all FL algorithms, we distributed the training data across M=50ğ‘€50M=50 clients and performed 100 rounds of training. Each client conducted 5 local training epochs per round. The batch size was set at 64, and we explored learning rates within the range [1e-2, 5e-3, 1e-3, 5e-4]. For FedAvgÂ McMahan etÂ al. [2017], clients perform standard stochastic gradient descent (SGD) updates as ClientOPT and upload their gradients to the central server. On the server side, the global model is updated using SGD as ServerOPT with the received gradients from the clients. FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. [2018] introduces a proximal term during local client training as their ClientOPT, to address data heterogeneity issues by preventing significant drifts in client model updates. It employs a weighted average for aggregation and updates the global model using SGD, similar to ServerOPT in FedAvg. We set the proximal term coefficient parameter Î¼=1ğœ‡1\mu=1 for the proximal term coefficient in FedProx. ScaffoldÂ Karimireddy etÂ al. [2019] employs client-variance reduction as its ClientOPT and corrects model drifts in local updates by introducing control variates. For ServerOPT, Scaffold incorporates the clientsâ€™ gradients and control variates for aggregation, and updates the global model using SGD. FedDynÂ Acar etÂ al. [2021] dynamically adjusts the local objectives by incorporating two regularizers as ClientOPT to ensure that the local optimum aligns asymptotically with the stationary points of the global objective. We set the parameter Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 as commonly used in the literature, and the local model is updated using SGD. Additionally, they introduce their server update as ServerOPT through the use of server state vectors. FedNovaÂ Wang etÂ al. [2020b] uses normalized stochastic gradients as ClientOPT to compensate for data imbalances across clients, and then introduces a weighted rescaling process as their ServerOPT. We run all experiments on a 3-GPU cluster of Tesla V100 GPUs, with each GPU having 32GB of memory.

B.1 Calibration on Centralized Learning

We present train-time calibration methods for traditional centralized training in TableÂ 6. We found that most of these methods effectively calibrate in centralized settings, maintaining accuracy and exhibiting lower calibration errors.

B.2 Additional Results of Calibration on FL

This section explores the performance of each calibration method on different datasets and data distributions for various FL algorithms. To ensure consistency in our experiments, most of the configuration remains unchanged. Specifically, we set the number of clients (Mğ‘€M) to 50 and the total number of federated rounds (Tğ‘‡T) to 100, with each client performing E=5ğ¸5E=5 epochs of local training. Additionally, the hyperparameter search space and the details for each FL algorithm are consistent, as detailed in AppendixÂ A. TablesÂ 7, Â 8, Â 9, and 10 display the performance and calibration metrics of various FL algorithms on the MNIST dataset across IID and non-IID conditions, with Î±ğ›¼\alpha values of 0.5, 0.1, and 0.05, respectively. Similarly, TablesÂ 11, Â 12, Â 13, and Â 14 present the performance and calibration metrics of different FL algorithms on the CIFAR-10 dataset under IID and non-IID conditions, with corresponding Î±ğ›¼\alpha values of 0.5, 0.1, and 0.05, respectively. Across these experimental results, which consider various data distribution setups and different datasets, our generic framework NUCFL consistently demonstrates superiority over the baseline by achieving lower calibration error. The performance improvements of NUCFL with different configurations, such as various similarity measurements and different auxiliary calibration losses, highlight the effectiveness and flexibility of our method.

B.3 Mitigating Over/Under-Confidence

In addition to the over-confidence examples discussed in SectionÂ 5.2, we also observe cases of under-confidence in FL algorithms. FigureÂ 5 presents the reliability histograms for non-IID (Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5) FedAvg using the MNIST dataset, where the results show a gap that exceeds the diagonal line, indicating under-confidence issues. While over-confidence is often viewed as more problematic in deep neural networks for real-world applications, under-confidence can also pose challenges in specific scenarios. For example, in a medical diagnosis scenario, a threshold of 0.95 for negative predictions means that any instance classified as negative with a probability â‰¤\leq 0.95 requires manual review. An underconfident model may classify an instance as negative with a probability of 0.51, suggesting a true probability of correctness that is at least 0.51, yet this does not clarify whether it surpasses the threshold. This leads to compulsory manual inspection regardless of the actual correctness, thus increasing the workload. Among all the figures, we see that our proposed method effectively calibrates FedAvg and exhibits a smaller gap (red region), demonstrating improved performance over other approaches.

B.4 Comparison with FedCal

This section presents additional experimental results and comparisons with FedCalÂ Peng etÂ al. [2024] from SectionÂ 5.2. TableÂ 15 provides complete comparisons across different datasets. The results in TableÂ 15 indicate that our proposed NUCFL outperforms FedCal. FedCal improves local client calibration using a local scaler design and aggregates these scalers to create a global scaler for the global model. However, relying solely on an aggregated scaler from local clients can lower global ECE but may neglect crucial interactions between global and local calibration needs. Our method accounts for these interactions, mitigating biases toward local heterogeneity and more effectively meeting global calibration requirements.
